explanation: The line "if S in A == T in A:" uses chained comparison/membership and doesn't compare the two boolean expressions as intended. It was interpreted as "S in (A == T)" which is wrong. I fixed it by explicitly comparing the two boolean results with parentheses: "if (S in A) == (T in A):" so the condition is True when S and T are either both in A (even permutations) or both not in A (odd permutations).
fixed_code:
S=input()
T=input()
A=["R G B","B R G","G B R"]
if (S in A) == (T in A):
    print("Yes")
else:
    print("No")
